item.title: Summer add a quote by Madeleine L'Engle
item.description: "You have to write the book that wants to be written. And if the book will be too difficult for grown-ups, then you write it for children." -- Madeleine L'Engle

item.title: Summer add a quote by Voltaire
item.description: "Let us read, and let us dance; these two amusements will never do any harm to the world." -- Voltaire

item.title: Summer add a quote by Michelangelo
item.description: "Read the heart and not the letter for the pen cannot draw near the good intent." -- Michelangelo

item.title: Summer add a quote by Theodore Roosevelt
item.description: "Far and away the best prize that life has to offer is the chance to work hard at work worth doing." -- Theodore Roosevelt

item.title: Summer add a quote by Michelangelo
item.description: "With few words I shall make thee understand my soul." -- Michelangelo

item.title: Summer add a quote by Madeleine L'Engle
item.description: "In my dreams, I never have an age." -- Madeleine L'Engle

item.title: Summer add a quote by George Meredith
item.description: "A witty woman is a treasure; a witty beauty is a power." -- George Meredith

item.title: Summer add a quote by Henri Frédéric Amiel
item.description: "A modest garden contains, for those who know how to look and to wait, more instruction than a library." -- Henri Frédéric Amiel

item.title: Summer add a quote by Dorothy Parker
item.description: "Beauty is only skin deep, but ugly goes clean to the bone." -- Dorothy Parker

item.title: Summer add a quote by Voltaire
item.description: "It is with books as with men: a very small number play a great part." -- Voltaire

item.title: Summer add a quote by Vincent Van Gogh
item.description: "It is with the reading of books the same as with looking at pictures; one must, without doubt, without hesitations, with assurance, admire what is beautiful." -- Vincent Van Gogh

item.title: Summer add a quote by Jonathan Swift
item.description: "Books, the children of the brain." -- Jonathan Swift

item.title: Summer add a quote by John Ruskin
item.description: "All books are divisible into two classes: the books of the hours, and the books of all Time." -- John Ruskin

item.title: Summer add a quote by C.S. Richardson
item.description: "A man can see a hundred women, lust for a thousand more, but it is one scent that will open his eyes and turn him to love." -- C.S. Richardson

item.title: Summer add a quote by Judy Blume
item.description: "[I]t's not just the books under fire now that worry me. It is the books that will never be written. The books that will never be read. And all due to the fear of censorship. As always, young readers will be the real losers." -- Judy Blume

item.title: Summer add a quote by Terence
item.description: "I am a human being, so nothing human is strange to me." -- Terence

item.title: Summer add a quote by Doris Lessing
item.description: "There is only one way to read, which is to browse in libraries and bookshops, picking up books that attract you, reading only those, dropping them when they bore you, skipping the parts that drag-and never, never reading anything because you feel you ought, or because it is part of a trend or a movement. Remember that the book which bores you when you are twenty or thirty will open doors for you when you are forty or fifty-and vise versa. Don’t read a book out of its right time for you. " -- Doris Lessing

item.title: Summer add a quote by Doris Lessing
item.description: "Ideally, what should be said to every child, repeatedly, throughout his or her school life is something like this: 'You are in the process of being indoctrinated. We have not yet evolved a system of education that is not a system of indoctrination. We are sorry, but it is the best we can do. What you are being taught here is an amalgam of current prejudice and the choices of this particular culture. The slightest look at history will show how impermanent these must be. You are being taught by people who have been able to accommodate themselves to a regime of thought laid down by their predecessors. It is a self-perpetuating system. Those of you who are more robust and individual than others will be encouraged to leave and find ways of educating yourself — educating your own judgements. Those that stay must remember, always, and all the time, that they are being moulded and patterned to fit into the narrow and particular needs of this particular society." -- Doris Lessing

item.title: Summer add a quote by Doris Lessing
item.description: "Remember that for all the books we have in print, are as many that have never reached print, have never been written down-even now, in this age of compulsive reverence for the written word, history, even social ethic, are taught by means of stories, and the people who have been conditioned into thinking only in terms of what is written-and unfortunately nearly all the products of our educational system can do no more than this-are missing what is before their eyes. For instance, the real history of Africa is still in the custody of black storytellers and wise men, black historians, medicine men: it is a verbal history, still kept safe from the white man and his predations. Everywhere, if you keep your mind open, you will find the words <i>not</i> written down. So never let the printed page be your master. Above all, you should know that the fact that you have to spend one year, or two years, on one book, or one author means that you are badly taught-you should have been taught to read your way from one sympathy to another, you should be learning to follow you own intuitive feeling about what you need; that is what you should have been developing, not the way to quote from other people." -- Doris Lessing

item.title: Summer add a quote by Samuel Johnson
item.description: "Knowledge is of two kinds. We know a subject ourselves, or we know where we can find information on it." -- Samuel Johnson

item.title: Summer add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "The person, be it gentleman or lady, who has not pleasure in a good novel, must be intolerably stupid." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Summer add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Run mad as often as you choose, but do not faint!" -- Jane Austen

item.title: Summer add a quote by Candice Bergen
item.description: "It takes a long time to become a person." -- Candice Bergen

item.title: Summer add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Follies and nonsense, whims and inconsistencies do divert me, I own, and I laugh at them whenever I can." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Summer add a quote by Edith Wharton
item.description: "There was once a little girl who was so very intelligent that her parents feared that she would die. But an aged aunt, who had crossed the Atlantic in a sailing-vessel, said, 'My dears, let her marry the first man she falls in love with, and she will make such a fool of herself that it will probably save her life." -- Edith Wharton

item.title: Summer add a quote by Jonathan Safran Foer
item.description: "If there is no love in the world, we will make a new world, and we will give it walls, and we will furnish it with soft, red interiors, from the inside out, and give it a knocker that resonates like a diamond falling to a jeweller's felt so that we should never hear it. Love me, because love doesn't exist, and I have tried everything that does." -- Jonathan Safran Foer

item.title: Summer add a quote by Charlotte Brontë
item.description: "But I don't mean to flatter you: if you are cast in a different mould to the majority, it is no merit of yours: Nature did it." -- Charlotte Brontë

item.title: Summer add a quote by Charlotte Brontë
item.description: "I envy you your peace of mind, your clean conscience, your unpolluted memory. Little girl, a memory without blot of contamination must be an exquisite treasure-an inexhaustible source of pure refreshment: is it not?" -- Charlotte Brontë

item.title: Summer add a quote by Ivan Doig
item.description: "Nightly awaits that sweet address Principality of Sleep Happy Land of Forgetfullness" -- Ivan Doig

item.title: Summer add a quote by Baldassare Castiglione
item.description: "Outward beauty is a true sign of inner goodness. This loveliness, indeed, is impressed upon the body in varying degrees as a token by which the soul can be recognized for what it is, just as with trees the beauty of the blossom testifies to the goodness of the fruit." -- Baldassare Castiglione
